title: [P1 BUG FIX] Cumulative aggregations with multiple breakouts should reset counts when values of breakouts other than change
body:
**:warning: :warning: :warning: IMPORTANT NOTE ABOUT TABLES BELOW: THE ORDER OF THINGS WAS SWITCHED IN FOLLOW-ON PR #42131 -- PLEASE DO NOT CITE THEM :warning: :warning: :warning:**

Fixes #2862

For queries with more than one breakout we were previously doing cumulative counts or sums across the entire result set, e.g.

| city | date       | count | cumulative_count |
|------|------------|-------|----|
| LBC  | 2024-01-01 | 10    | 10 |
| LBC  | 2024-01-02 | 2     | 12 |
| LBC  | 2024-01-02 | 4     | 16 |
| SF   | 2024-01-01 | 3     | 19 |
| SF   | 2024-01-01 | 1     | 20 |
| SF   | 2024-01-02 | 2     | 22 |

[Everyone **hated** this behavior](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/2862):

> Just a note that we received customer feedback that the current behavior is confusing

> The current behaviour produces incorrect results, it's not just confusing.

> The current behaviour produces results that are incorrect/misleading in that they do not match the question implied by the question builder choices

> This is so wrong!

> This should really get fixed.

> No other tool operates in this way that I'm aware of (aware of 2 others that do the "right" thing).


So this PR updates things to reset the cumulative count/sum when one of the breakout values besides the last change:

| city | date       | count | cumulative_count |
|------|------------|-------|----|
| LBC  | 2024-01-01 | 10    | 10 | 
| LBC  | 2024-01-02 | 2     | 12 | 
| LBC  | 2024-01-02 | 4     | 16 | 
| SF   | 2024-01-01 | 3     | 3  |
| SF   | 2024-01-01 | 1     | 4  |
| SF   | 2024-01-02 | 2     | 6  |

In the new SQL window function implementation, instead of generating something like

```sql
SELECT
  city,
  created_at_month,
  sum(sum(total)) OVER (
    ORDER BY city, created_at_month
    ROWS UNBOUNDED PRECEDING
  ) AS cumulative_sum
FROM orders
GROUP BY city, created_at_month
ORDER BY city, created_at_month
```

we now generate

```sql
SELECT
  city,
  created_at_month,
  sum(sum(total)) OVER (
    PARTITION BY city
    ORDER BY created_at_month
    ROWS UNBOUNDED PRECEDING
  ) AS cumulative_sum
FROM orders
GROUP BY city, created_at_month
ORDER BY city, created_at_month
```

`PARTITION BY <output column number>` did not seem to work, and it seemed dumb to have a mix of output column numbers and actual expressions e.g.

```sql
SELECT
  city,
  created_at_month,
  sum(sum(total)) OVER (
    PARTITION BY city
    ORDER BY 2
    ROWS UNBOUNDED PRECEDING
  ) AS cumulative_sum
FROM orders
GROUP BY city, created_at_month
ORDER BY city, created_at_month
```

So I just ended up removing the alternate `:sql/window-functions.order-by-output-column-numbers` implementation I added last week and updated things so every driver works the same way; since this made drivers fussy I tweaked things so the extra stage transformation that was previously BigQuery-only is done automatically for all SQL queries with cumulative aggregations. This makes the driver changelog for 50 considerably simpler since people don't need to worry about picking one implementation or the other, things should just work out of the box for everyone.

**:warning: :warning: :warning: IMPORTANT NOTE ABOUT TABLES ABOVE: THE ORDER OF THINGS WAS SWITCHED IN FOLLOW-ON PR #42131 -- PLEASE DO NOT CITE THEM :warning: :warning: :warning:**
author: camsaul
labels: [('no-backport', 'Do not backport this PR to any branch')]

title: Don't say we'll cache archived models
body:
When we actually run the job to cache models, we select "refreshable models", which selects `PersistedInfo` where:

- the `state` is something refreshable, and

- the question marked for caching is actually a model, and

- the question hasn't been archived.

However, when we selected `PersistedInfo`s to display to the user, we didn't apply any conditions. Instead, we included PersistedInfo where the question was not a model, or where the question had been archived.

To prevent confusion, let's hide these.

Fixes https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/41318
author: johnswanson
labels: [('backport', 'Automatically create PR on current release branch on merge'), ('.Team/AdminWebapp', 'Admin and Webapp team')]

title: New default permissions for groups

Follow-up to https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/40869

title: Cloud Migration Feature
body:
This PR includes the following cloud migration endpoints along with the FE user experience for migrating an instance:
```[tasklist]
### Tasks
- [x] `defsetting read-only-mode`
- [x] `metabase.api.cloud-migration` ns
- [x] `cloud_migration` table
- [x] POST `/cloud-migration`
- [x] GET `/cloud-migration`
- [x] PUT `/cloud-migration/cancel`
```

title: No implicit any on callbacks
body:
Closes https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/41271

### Description
Update types in preparation for a change to the `useCallback` type in React 18. This PR should have minimal impact to actual functionality, and largely just provide more specific typing to `useCallback` handlers

### How to verify
Geen CI

title: Re-wire the `Users` entity to use RTK Query under the hood
body:
### What does this PR accomplish?
- It adds new RTK Query api endpoints
- It migrates `Users` entity to use new RTK Query endpoints under the hood
- Even though this was not a part of this task/milestone, it also migrates `updatePassword` from the hook to the new RTK mutation
- It removes some unused `userApi` keys

Resolves https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/40812.

### What was out of the scope?
- Creating new RTK Query endpoints for the remaining `userAPi` entries:
    - list
    - current
    - update_qbnewb

They are not used by entities, and will be migrated in the milestone 2 of #40788
author: nemanjaglumac
labels: [('no-backport', 'Do not backport this PR to any branch'), ('.Team/Querying', '')]

title: Bump tar from 6.1.11 to 6.2.1
body:
Bumps [tar](https://github.com/isaacs/node-tar) from 6.1.11 to 6.2.1.
Release notes

Sourced from tar's releases.

v6.1.13

6.1.13 (2022-12-07)

Dependencies

  • cc4e0dd #343 bump minipass from 3.3.6 to 4.0.0

v6.1.12

6.1.12 (2022-10-31)

Bug Fixes

  • 57493ee #332 ensuring close event is emited after stream has ended (@‚Äãwebark)
  • b003c64 #314 replace deprecated String.prototype.substr() (#314) (@‚ÄãCommanderRoot, @‚Äãlukekarrys)

Documentation

  • f129929 #313 remove dead link to benchmarks (#313) (@‚Äãyetzt)
  • c1faa9f add examples/explanation of using tar.t (@‚Äãisaacs)
Changelog

Sourced from tar's changelog.

Changelog

7.0

  • Rewrite in TypeScript, provide ESM and CommonJS hybrid interface
  • Add tree-shake friendly exports, like import('tar/create') and import('tar/read-entry') to get individual functions or classes.
  • Add chmod option that defaults to false, and deprecate noChmod. That is, reverse the default option regarding explicitly setting file system modes to match tar entry settings.
  • Add processUmask option to avoid having to call process.umask() when chmod: true (or noChmod: false) is set.

6.2

  • Add support for brotli compression
  • Add maxDepth option to prevent extraction into excessively deep folders.

6.1

  • remove dead link to benchmarks (#313) (@‚Äãyetzt)
  • add examples/explanation of using tar.t (@‚Äãisaacs)
  • ensure close event is emited after stream has ended (@‚Äãwebark)
  • replace deprecated String.prototype.substr() (@‚ÄãCommanderRoot, @‚Äãlukekarrys)

6.0

  • Drop support for node 6 and 8
  • fix symlinks and hardlinks on windows being packed with \-style path targets

5.0

  • Address unpack race conditions using path reservations
  • Change large-numbers errors from TypeError to Error
  • Add TAR_* error codes
  • Raise TAR_BAD_ARCHIVE warning/error when there are no valid entries found in an archive
  • do not treat ignored entries as an invalid archive
  • drop support for node v4
  • unpack: conditionally use a file mapping to write files on Windows
  • Set more portable 'mode' value in portable mode
  • Set portable gzip option in portable mode

... (truncated)

Commits
  • bef7b1e 6.2.1
  • fe8cd57 prevent extraction in excessively deep subfolders
  • fe7ebfd remove security.md
  • 5bc9d40 6.2.0
  • fe1ef5e changelog 6.2
  • e483220 get rid of npm lint stuff
  • 689928a ci that works outside of npm org
  • db6f539 file inference improvements for .tbr and .tgz
  • 336fa8f refactor: dry and other pr comments
  • eeba222 chore: lint fixes
  • Additional commits viewable in compare view

[![Dependabot compatibility score](https://dependabot-badges.githubapp.com/badges/compatibility_score?dependency-name=tar&package-manager=npm_and_yarn&previous-version=6.1.11&new-version=6.2.1)](https://docs.github.com/en/github/managing-security-vulnerabilities/about-dependabot-security-updates#about-compatibility-scores) Dependabot will resolve any conflicts with this PR as long as you don't alter it yourself. You can also trigger a rebase manually by commenting `@dependabot rebase`. [//]: # (dependabot-automerge-start) [//]: # (dependabot-automerge-end) ---
Dependabot commands and options
You can trigger Dependabot actions by commenting on this PR: - `@dependabot rebase` will rebase this PR - `@dependabot recreate` will recreate this PR, overwriting any edits that have been made to it - `@dependabot merge` will merge this PR after your CI passes on it - `@dependabot squash and merge` will squash and merge this PR after your CI passes on it - `@dependabot cancel merge` will cancel a previously requested merge and block automerging - `@dependabot reopen` will reopen this PR if it is closed - `@dependabot close` will close this PR and stop Dependabot recreating it. You can achieve the same result by closing it manually - `@dependabot show ignore conditions` will show all of the ignore conditions of the specified dependency - `@dependabot ignore this major version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this major version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `@dependabot ignore this minor version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this minor version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `@dependabot ignore this dependency` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this dependency (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) You can disable automated security fix PRs for this repo from the [Security Alerts page](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/network/alerts).

title: fix bar min height can be less than 1
body: Closes https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/41291 ### Description When a bar series have a wide extent so that small values are estimated as less than 1px they can appear invisible which can be misleading. This PR sets min bar height to 1px as it was in the previous implementation. ### How to verify Check that small values on wide extent are still visible for bar charts: ``` select 1 x, 100000000 y union all select 2, 100 union all select 3, 1 ``` ### Demo Before After Stats ### Checklist - [x] Tests have been added/updated to cover changes in this PR

title: EE endpoint for deleting CSV uploads
body:
Closes https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/41118

### Description

~~Pretty self explanatory.~~ This turned out to be less straight forward than I anticipated. See comments.

~~I was hoping to reuse sync code for the app db clean-up, but it turned out that most of the child resources never get cleaned-up, and those that do expect the table to have been marked inactive, not deleted. Since there's no way to recover these randomly named tables, there's no point in leaving any trace.~~

~~I'm not sure happy with the way the deletes cascade - besides "breaking" encapsulation (none were encapsulated to begin with), ~~there's no mechanism for a failing test if a new kind of model is added that we don't clean up.~~ Update: I've added a crude mechanism.~~

### How to verify

Needs FE work to test via web app.
author: crisptrutski
labels: [('no-backport', 'Do not backport this PR to any branch'), ('.Team/Workflows', 'aka BEC')]

', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 4, 10, 21, 58, 16, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2048539829, 'issue_id': 2236481135, 'author': 'crisptrutski', 'body': 'Potential extras left out of scope for now: audit logs and snowplow events.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 4, 10, 22, 27, 8, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2049212149, 'issue_id': 2236481135, 'author': 'crisptrutski', 'body': '> Are we sure we want to delete the tables but not deactivate them? Hmm, you've sown some doubt. My thinking was "you can already archive the table", but I realize I was confusing the auto-generated model with the table instance. > A side effect of deleting tables is that it'll delete all cards with these tables as sources. I haven't checked, but my assumption was that only MBQL cards with the given table in their "primary" from position would have the corresponding `table_id`. This seems like a good enough time as any to check that. > And I'm pretty sure that we don't want to delete cards My feeling is that we'd at least want to delete the default model created by the upload, and my thinking for the remainder was that since there's no way to create "the same" table with an upload this resources are now permanently orphaned, versus tables that could be missing on sync e.g. due to a transient operational issue. > There is a couple of chat([slack](https://metaboat.slack.com/archives/CKZEMT1MJ/p1710240468597929)) around archive / delete lately so I want to make sure we're conscious about this. Thanks for linking back to that thread, somehow I'd forgotten this relevant quote from Sameer: "We offer somewhat out of the way hard deletes to satisfy legal (aka GDPR or similar) requirements`". That does suggest I'm going against the grain here. What is the customer experience when they try to open a broken card, would they be able to re-route it to use another table? e.g. the customer re-uploaded it, perhaps they didn't realize they could just use "replace". You've convinced me this needs more thought and wider input. My original plan was just to trigger a manual sync on the table, but I was surprised to find that barely touches the related resources. I've just discovered from updating the test to just use sync that actually we have cascading deletes on our foreign keys. I'm so used to highly scalable systems that I forget that FKs are a thing, and that obviously we can't leave any orphans around. I've double checked the database and all the models I listed out have FK constraints ü§¶ Update: Nail in the coffin, I've just noticed this in the product doc: > Secondarily they can also choose to archive questions and models that use these tables as their base data source. OK, so this seems to settle it that we simply want to deactivate the table. There's a *whole bunch of stuff* collapsed under "Answered Questions" that I hadn't realized was populated, so I'm reading through that now - for a start this route needs to be gated to EE.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 4, 11, 8, 42, 35, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2051950340, 'issue_id': 2236481135, 'author': 'crisptrutski', 'body': '* **#41293** üëà * `master` This stack of pull requests is managed by Graphite. Learn more about stacking.

Join @crisptrutski and the rest of your teammates on Graphite ', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 4, 12, 15, 9, 35, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2051977052, 'issue_id': 2236481135, 'author': 'crisptrutski', 'body': 'There have been some pretty major changes since the early version: - The route has moved to EE - The route now supports "bulk" deletion - There's no way to bulk drop the user tables, so we handle each table atomically. - Given this fact, perhaps there's no point making it a batch API, and the FE should just hit multiple routes? - This could even result in better UI as they could show a progress meter for really large lists. - So.. perhaps I'll roll this back, but first I'll speak to Arakaki and FE engineer assigned to this. - Given the feature-gating and batching, I gave up on an "agnostic" route which could expand to other table types. - The table record and its descendants are no longer deleted, we simply deactivate the table. - We call sync on the table, but it doesn't really do anything. Some more things happen on the next db sync, like removing related privileges, and perhaps we want this to happen pre-emptively. - We wouldn't want to slow this route down too much though, so perhaps that would be async anyway. - It's opt-in to archive the the cards using this as their "primary table" (Prod Doc wording) - Going to clarify the scope of cards this covers with Arakaki. Given the lack of clarity around archiving, I've held off on testing that for now. I may decide to remove the feature all-together for now and implement it in a later PR if the scope is wider, but thought it was worth getting feedback on the API design earlier.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 4, 12, 15, 25, 38, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2056362487, 'issue_id': 2236481135, 'author': 'github-actions[bot]', 'body': ' [Codenotify](https://github.com/sourcegraph/codenotify): Notifying subscribers in CODENOTIFY files for diff 92181ab1530827fd32468f24d8b0b5237c35e7ea...1ba59bb719f67dab5e17bff765dc9f376445f6ff. | Notify | File(s) | |-|-| | @alxnddr | frontend/src/metabase/visualizations/click-actions/Mode/Mode.ts

title: Split Permissions - "Permissions Help" UI Update
body: Closes #40852 ### Description Update the items and copy of the `Permissions Help` section to accommodate changes from the split permissions updates. No self-service description will only show to users if it's currently in their permissions graph. ### How to verify - Go to permission page in the database or group views. - Click the permissions help button in the top right hand corner ### Demo ### Checklist - [x] Tests have been added/updated to cover changes in this PR

title: Create example-dashboard-id setting
body:
This PR creates a new setting for embedding to use the dashboard created in https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/40753. The setting is called `example-dashboard-id` and stores the ID of the dashboard created with the new sample content.

The setting's value is an integer, and will be `nil` if the sample content was never created.

Important! If the dashboard is deleted, the setting is not updated. Clients need to check the existence of the dashboard.
author: calherries
labels: [('.Team/Workflows', 'aka BEC')]

title: Note the format_rows changes in the api changelog
body:
In 49, export formatting changed, but no option was available to users to retain the old export style (no formatting).

Whether or not this constitutes a breaking API change is a bit of a question.

In 49.3 (plus a fix in 49.5) the `format_rows` query parameter has been added to allow for unformatted downloads/exports.

title: Add most used functions to suggestions when they open
body: Closes https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/41237 ### Description Adds the most used functions to the list of suggestions when the expression editor opens. To accomplish this, this PR: - adds a list of popular functions - returns that list when suggestions for the empty string are requested - adds grouping to the suggestion dropdown - adds a (permanent) link to all functions in the suggestion dropdown ### How to verify Describe the steps to verify that the changes are working as expected. 1. New question ‚Üí Sample dataset ‚Üí Orders 2. Click "Custom Column" 3. The expression editor should open with the dropdown for suggestions opened and showing most popular suggestions. ### Demo ### Checklist - [x] Tests have been added/updated to cover changes in this PR ### Note This PR is a follow up of https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/41236, so it contains changes from it.

title: Fix embed download endpoint
body:
Fixes: #40959 
Fixes: #41240

We have added format_rows as a query parameter. In most endpoints this just works fine.

Here, however, the problem is that we use query parameters to pass parameter values. We run some validation over these provided parameter values (eg. don't allow a user to over ride a 'locked' parameter). Since we have these 2 different use cases for query parameters, the validation was failing on :format_rows, which isn't expected to exist at all.

Here, I dissoc the :format_rows key prior to this validation step, so normal validation can continue.
author: adam-james-v

title: Remove -Xmx4g option from :cloverage alias
body: https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/41213 bumped the `:ci` alias in deps.edn to set 12g of RAM as both the minimum and maximum heap size. But this is in conflict with the `:cloverage` alias which sets a max heap size of 4g, causing the cloverage job to error on master. I think we can just remove the memory setting from the `:cloverage` alias and use the `:ci` one for both.
author: noahmoss
labels: [('backport', 'Automatically create PR on current release branch on merge'), ('.Team/AdminWebapp', 'Admin and Webapp team'), ('run-cloverage', 'Runs Cloverage (BE test coverage job) on this PR')]

You can set the `.metabase-lib/no-change` label to override for a change that edits the namespace without materially changing the API.

title: Fix snowflake's delete-old-datasets! for tests
body:
This PR fixes the root cause of the problem causing redshift failures in CI ([example](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/actions/runs/8628851832/job/23651827525?pr=41068#step:3:494))

[Slack context](https://metaboat.slack.com/archives/C5XHN8GLW/p1712743631946979)

Previously the `DROP DATABASE ...` statements we were executing in `delete-old-datasets!` were failing because the database name didn't match what was in the database. 

e.g. this is a typical database name being returned from `conn.getCatalogs()`:

`2024_04_08_fb38bcb0_58ff_4a05_a912_87071e9a6218_Default-Schema-Test`

But we would lower-case it before executing DROP DATABASE, like so:

`DROP DATABASE 2024_04_08_fb38bcb0_58ff_4a05_a912_87071e9a6218_default-schema-test`

That would result in the following error:
```
Database '"2024_04_08_fb38bcb0_58ff_4a05_a912_87071e9a6218_default-schema-test"' does not exist or not authorized.
```

It's not clear to me why the database names are being Sentence-Cased but we definitely shouldn't be lower-casing them.
author: calherries
labels: [('backport', 'Automatically create PR on current release branch on merge'), ('.Team/Workflows', 'aka BEC')]
comments_list: [{'comment_id': 2047486791, 'issue_id': 2235521331, 'author': 'crisptrutski', 'body': "I wonder whether this wasn't related to some quirk with an older version of Snowflake or its driver?", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 4, 10, 13, 3, 22, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2047489700, 'issue_id': 2235521331, 'author': 'crisptrutski', 'body': "It's a pity that old comment comes from a mammoth PR so its hard to infer the reason.", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 4, 10, 13, 4, 44, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2047767313, 'issue_id': 2235521331, 'author': 'calherries', 'body': "> I wonder whether this wasn't related to some quirk with an older version of Snowflake or its driver?\r\n\r\nunsure, I think we'll never know", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 4, 10, 14, 50, 31, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2047813399, 'issue_id': 2235521331, 'author': 'github-actions[bot]', 'body': '@calherries Did you forget to add a milestone to the issue for this PR? _[When and where should I add a milestone?](https://www.notion.so/metabase/Metabase-Branching-Strategy-6eb577d5f61142aa960a626d6bbdfeb3?pvs=4#3dea255ffa3b4f74942a227844e889fa)_', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 4, 10, 15, 8, 12, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}]

title: Add Schedule strategy to Admin > Performance
body:
Closes #41424

Adds a Schedule strategy to the Admin / Performance page

![image](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/assets/130925/d78ff74d-df1c-477a-b157-a0c3f21a861b)

[Loom](https://www.loom.com/share/5623cd5d772e417ba2e58c29ae1b8c14?sid=9844f0db-5bb1-4d35-af9b-206d263f5516)

As discussed with @luizarakaki, rather than modify the legacy `SchedulePicker` to work with this use case, I made a new version of it - a `Schedule` component - that uses Mantine and a better (though imperfect) approach to localization. For now, the dropdowns are not vertically aligned in this Schedule picker - something I can try to remedy later if that is important.

Tests for the Schedule component will be added in a follow-up PR.
author: rafpaf
labels: [('no-backport', 'Do not backport this PR to any branch'), ('.Team/AdminWebapp', 'Admin and Webapp team')]

title: docs - drop note on sandboxes
body:
Caching is compatible with data sandboxing.

See https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/14388.
author: jeff-bruemmer
labels: [('Type:Documentation', ''), ('backport', 'Automatically create PR on current release branch on merge'), ('.Team/Workflows', 'aka BEC')]
comments_list:
[{'comment_id': 2049153048, 'issue_id': 2234324292, 'author': 'piranha', 'body': "Caching is indeed compatible with data sandboxing - there is some code designed to specifically be careful around that, see `middleware/cache.clj`:

```
  ;; Query will already have `info.hash` if it's a userland query. It's not the same hash, because this is calculated
  ;; after normalization, instead of before. This is necessary to make caching work properly with sandboxed users, see
  ;; #14388.
  (let [query-hash      (qp.util/query-hash query)
```", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 4, 11, 8, 6, 5, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2050067501, 'issue_id': 2234324292, 'author': 'github-actions[bot]', 'body': '@jeff-bruemmer Did you forget to add a milestone to the issue for this PR? _[When and where should I add a milestone?](https://www.notion.so/metabase/Metabase-Branching-Strategy-6eb577d5f61142aa960a626d6bbdfeb3?pvs=4#3dea255ffa3b4f74942a227844e889fa)_', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 4, 11, 16, 24, 28, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}]
comment_thread:
piranha on (2024-04-11 08:06:05 UTC): Caching is indeed compatible with data sandboxing - there is some code designed to specifically be careful around that, see `middleware/cache.clj`:

```
  ;; Query will already have `info.hash` if it's a userland query. It's not the same hash, because this is calculated
  ;; after normalization, instead of before. This is necessary to make caching work properly with sandboxed users, see
  ;; #14388.
  (let [query-hash      (qp.util/query-hash query)
```

github-actions[bot] on (2024-04-11 16:24:28 UTC): @jeff-bruemmer Did you forget to add a milestone to the issue for this PR? _[When and where should I add a milestone?](https://www.notion.so/metabase/Metabase-Branching-Strategy-6eb577d5f61142aa960a626d6bbdfeb3?pvs=4#3dea255ffa3b4f74942a227844e889fa)_

title: üöÄ üèéÔ∏è ‚è©Driver tests now take 28 minutes instead of 90 üöÄ üèéÔ∏è ‚è©
body:
We were setting `-Xmx2g` because CircleCI instances had 4 GB of memory total ~10 years ago, these days GitHub Actions runners have 16 GB of RAM. Let's make use of the extra RAM available to us.

Preliminary results have Postgres driver tests finishing in 28 minutes instead of timing out in 90 minutes. Yay

title: Remove native dataset from services
body:
### Description

This PR replaces the last instance of the `MetabaseApi.native` call with the new RTK Query endpoint (introduced in https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/40430).

It then removes unused query builder selector, and unused endpoint from MetabaseApi.

### How to verify
```sql
SELECT
  count(*)
FROM
  products
WHERE
  category = {{category}}
```

1. New native question -> Sample Dataset -> paste the query from above
2. An eye icon should appear ("Preview the query")
3. Click on it and you should see the preview modal with an error message (because we're missing a required parameter)
4. Enter a value in the filter "Gizmo"
5. Click on the preview again
6. You should see the preview modal with a query

### Demo
![Kapture 2024-04-30 at 16 40 01](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/assets/31325167/b303b179-68c3-4b8a-95ed-732633bfc03d)

### Checklist
The existing test coverage should suffice.

title: Preserve the original question name in a "save question" modal
body:
Resolves #41196
Reproduces #41196 

### Description

We're now initializing form values with the name and the description derived from the original question. If, for whatever reason, that question name is not available, we're falling back to auto-generated descriptive question name. And if even that doesn't work, we will leave the `name` field empty for user to populate.

### How to verify

1. Open any saved question (let's say that its name was "Foo")
2. Modify anything about that question (filter, sort, row limit)
3. Click on "Save"
4. Choose "Save as new question"
5. Make sure that the suggested pre-filled name in the form is still "Foo"

Run an associated E2E reproduction.

### Demo
![Kapture 2024-04-09 at 18 40 00](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/assets/31325167/05fe9c99-b077-43ca-8d2c-637bd5729c5e)

### Checklist
- [x] Tests have been added/updated to cover changes in this PR

title: Mitigate some redshift flakes
body: These tests were flaking for me all the time, so I'd like to mitigate the flakes by not dropping the tables. This approach has worked in the past.
author: calherries

title: add env var to enable css modules classnames linting
body:
‚ö†Ô∏è Please have a look at the [commits](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/41173/commits) to see a nice diff of the eslint file, as in one commit I'm changing it from .eslintrc to .eslintrc.json 

# Description

This is based off https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/40628 and adds a ENV to not make it crash vscode (explained later).

As team embedding is working on the css migration, we wanted a way to detect if we were referencing classnames that don't exist. After having tried a few tools @oisincoveney found `eslint-plugin-postcss-modules` to be the most promising and less invasive.

It does slow down eslint a bit though (I suspect it doesn't cache the parsing of index.css, and it parses it every time we import from that), and [it was breaking eslint completely on vscode](https://metaboat.slack.com/archives/C063Q3F1HPF/p1712047392130979?thread_ts=1711971943.265019&cid=C063Q3F1HPF).

To solve that I put the plugin behind a env var to make it "opt in" locally, and always make it run on CI.

It's also enabled on lint-staged, but it's only triggered by js/ts file changes. The reason is that a css change would technically require linting all js/ts files, which would take minutes, which is not something we want to do on a precommit.


# How to verify
- ci should fail and show the css errors on this pr: https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/41245
- by default, it should not be enabled in your IDE, so VScode shouldn't crash eslint
- if you want, you can open your IDE setting first the env and it should work
- it should work also if you set the env in .profile and log off/re-login

title: Fix unable to disable scan field values
body:
First part to fix https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/40715

This will fix it so that there will be no background jobs for scanning field values when creating or updating a DB with scan FV options: "Only when adding a new filter" or "Never, I'll do it myself."

I'll have another follow-up to introduce a migration that will remove all the existing scan field values jobs for existing DBs that turn off Scan field values.

title: Convert auto-bucket-datetimes middleware to MLv2
body:
Resolves #39834

Internal refactor. The main reason for this refactor is to make some other bugfixes I'm working on easier to do -- code is a lot simpler when using MLv2 internally.

Bonus stuff:

- I also added some new Kondo rules to enforce usage of the `lib.schema` or `legacy-mbql.schema` schemas in `metabase.lib` and the QP, as opposed to the ones used in the REST API/model stuff in `metabase.util.malli.schema` -- these versions are preferrable because they have the extra documentation added and keep `metabase.lib`'s dependencies on other parts of the codebase to a minimum.
- I enabled the prefer `update-keys` and `update-vals` over the Medley versions in the QP.
- I removed `qp.store/bulk-metadata` in favor of `lib.metadata/bulk-metadata-or-throw`, moving us one step closer to removing the QP store entirely (once all QP middleware uses MLv2 we can use the query itself for metadata)

title: Minimize echarts shape transitions
body:
### Description

Previously, we did not have any smooth shape transitions so this PR minimizes them by setting `animationDurationUpdate` to 1. If we set it to zero, then opacity transitions on hover won't work.

### How to verify

Check that charts do not have visible shape transitions when resizing, changing granularity.

title: fix echarts trend lines
body:
Closes https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/39604

### Description

The linked issue mentions 4 problematic questions but only one is caused by our changes. Two of the questions show different trend because the trend forumula in the `insights` object is different from what we are getting on stats.

**Bad**
question/14064 ‚Äî this PR should fix it by limiting the trend line range when custom y-axis range is specified
https://metaboat.slack.com/archives/C06G94JTWBS/p1706197726123329

**Unrelated**
question/2530 ‚Äî Different trend line function returned from the BE. Also, just refreshing the data sometimes returns different trend function.
https://metaboat.slack.com/archives/C06G94JTWBS/p1706198830603689
question/2862 ‚Äî Different trend line function returned from the BE
https://metaboat.slack.com/archives/C06G94JTWBS/p1706201653722559
question/839 ‚Äî Looks fine.
https://metaboat.slack.com/archives/C06G94JTWBS/p1706196346146919

### How to verify

1. Orders -> Cumulative sum of Total by Created At: Month
2. Enable trend line
3. Ensure it goes below zero
4. Disable auto y-axis range
5. Ensure the trend line does not expand the range of y-axis

### Demo

https://github.com/metabase/metabase/assets/14301985/de249b3d-1619-4863-b2d4-db4ae07a64a0

### Checklist

- [x] Tests have been added/updated to cover changes in this PR

title: [MBQL lib] Don't enforce expression types when converting from legacy
body:
These type checks are useful when constructing clauses with full MLv2
metadata available, but when converting from legacy the `:field` refs
have only `:base-type`.

If a column has its metadata overridden to eg. coerce a string or
integer into a date, its `:base-type` will remain `:type/Integer` or
`:type/Text` and the `:effective-type` will be `:type/Date` etc.

This change skips the type check while converting from legacy, and
while checking `can-run`. Eventually this should be replaced with
tracking `:effective-type` on refs or using real metdata, instead of
relying on the `:base-type` only.

Fixes #41122.
author: bshepherdson
labels: [('backport', 'Automatically create PR on current release branch on merge')]

title: Bugfix 38839 manually set axis position
body:
Fixes: #38839 

Prior to this, any time axes were all explicitly set `:left` or `:right` by the user, the `group-axes-at-once` function
would incorrectly return the map in the following form:

`{:left ["a" "b" "c"]}` which is incorrect. It must instead look like this:

`{"a" :left "b" :left "c" :left}`

This fixes the map shape and permits the user to explicitly set all axes to the left or to the right.

This dashboard:
![image](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/assets/21064735/bc06b941-5819-4687-b22f-b7ca7fd69bba)

(Note the first card has axes on the left and the second has them on the right)

Now correctly yields:
![image](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/assets/21064735/c0359cb3-4827-4398-8c3e-16e74e12cf12)
author: adam-james-v

title: Fix tags for self-referencing entities
body:
Epic https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/40788
Closes https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/40801
Closes https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/40798
Closes https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/40790

Extract helpers for tags where an entity can reference another entity. This is needed to make cache invalidation logic work. If an entity is referenced in the response, it should trigger refetch if it was mutated. 

Also migrates `popular-items` and `recent-items` entities.

How to verify:
- CI is green

title: Include usage count in upload table list
body:
References https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/36369

### Description

I failed to look through the mock-ups before, and see that we need to know the schema, created time, and number of questions / models using it.  The first two were already present, I just updated the test to demonstrate that, but the last one needed to be calculated. I don't see any reason that this number can't include metrics as well in future, so I haven't explicitly excluded them.

When SQL parsing is online we probably want to count the indirect usages as well, and probably MBQL joins etc too, but this is probably good enough for a v1.
author: crisptrutski
labels: [('no-backport', 'Do not backport this PR to any branch'), ('.Team/Workflows', 'aka BEC')]

title: increase activation distance for dashboard parameter dragging
body:
Closes https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/40914

### Description
Increase the activation distance for dragging parameters from 5px to 15px. This keeps the UX fairly nice while ensuring that the drag is more intentional. This will also impact dragging query parameters in native queries.

### How to verify

1. Go to a dashboard with filter params, and click edit
2. drag parameters to re-order them. Re-ordering should still work as it always has, but clicking and dragging < `15px` should still register as a click and open the side panel

### Demo
![chrome_Fb9alPPI1a](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/assets/1328979/77d80543-605a-4324-ad88-7e34be8fdc4b)

### Checklist
I wasn't able to come up with an e2e test that would simulate the behavior I was looking for. Triggering a click event on the draggable element always resulted in the side panel opening :/. Open to suggestions if anyone has ideas though!

- [ ] ~Tests have been added/updated to cover changes in this PR~
author: npfitz
labels: [('backport', 'Automatically create PR on current release branch on merge'), ('visual', 'Run Percy visual testing'), ('.Team/AdminWebapp', 'Admin and Webapp team')]

title: Add endpoint to list uploaded tables
body:
Closes https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/41114

### Description

This adds a new endpoint which exposes the uploaded tables visible to the current user.

The use case for this table is to present of views of tables that the user may want to archive. Despite the fact that this is a mutating use case, I decided to keep the filter on "read" permissions as:

1. There may be other use cases for this list.
2. We may want to explicitly show which tables they can view but not delete.
author: crisptrutski
labels: [('no-backport', 'Do not backport this PR to any branch'), ('.Team/Workflows', 'aka BEC')]

We also have pagination for search results which are implemented in a similar way. Here's the PR for [collection pagination](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/15769) for reference.", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 4, 8, 14, 55, 38, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2043038843, 'issue_id': 2230656096, 'author': 'calherries', 'body': 'Also we'll need to update this to make sure `:schema` is an empty string instead of `nil`, like in https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/41052/files#diff-be35e21c63ee8c431fa5e505dfc2749e2b7354f2b0f739ca3974d0ddff47c002R52-R54. Even if the admin page doesn't care about nil vs am empty string, if these results are cached on the FE we'll have a bug where the FE expects `""` but the cached schema is `nil`.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 4, 8, 15, 20, 14, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2043111353, 'issue_id': 2230656096, 'author': 'iethree', 'body': "I'm very comfortable with v1 lacking pagination. I kind of hate how aggressively paginated collections are. Some sort of pagination will probably be necessary, but only for instances on the order of tens of thousands of tables", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 4, 8, 15, 52, 48, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2043518438, 'issue_id': 2230656096, 'author': 'crisptrutski', 'body': '@calherries I naively assumed any pagination would be purely client-side. Given the precedent of the non-paginated "all tables" endpoint (which also hydrates each row), I figured scaling was fine - "make it work, then make it scale". Thanks for calling this out and pointing to prior work - one of a few things now that would have benefited from a short tech design doc. @iethree Around collection pagination, are we dissatisfied with anything about the mechanism itself, or just how many result we're returning per page? Curious how to approach future pagination when we need it.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 4, 8, 19, 41, 17, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2044269507, 'issue_id': 2230656096, 'author': 'iethree', 'body': "> @iethree Around collection pagination, are we dissatisfied with anything about the mechanism itself, or just how many result we're returning per page? Curious how to approach future pagination when we need it. There's nothing wrong with the actual pagination mechanism - it's just kind of stupid that we paginate at all when we're usually looking at only hundreds of records per collection, we could provide a much better user experience on the frontend if we just paginated there.", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 4, 9, 6, 53, 47, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2044340420, 'issue_id': 2230656096, 'author': 'crisptrutski', 'body': 'In practice do we have a limit on how many records can be added to a collection?', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 4, 9, 7, 39, 3, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2044373452, 'issue_id': 2230656096, 'author': 'calherries', 'body': 'I don't think so. And Cam added pagination to improve the performance of loading large collections. Our own "Our Analytics" collection has >500 items in it, so it's not hard to believe there are collections out there with thousands of items.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 4, 9, 7, 55, 21, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2044571038, 'issue_id': 2230656096, 'author': 'tsmacdonald', 'body': 'Possibly related: https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/30115#', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 4, 9, 9, 37, 14, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}]

Given the precedent of the non-paginated "all tables" endpoint (which also hydrates each row), I figured scaling was fine - "make it work, then make it scale". Thanks for calling this out and pointing to prior work - one of a few things now that would have benefited from a short tech design doc. @iethree Around collection pagination, are we dissatisfied with anything about the mechanism itself, or just how many result we're returning per page? Curious how to approach future pagination when we need it. iethree on (2024-04-09 06:53:47 UTC): There's nothing wrong with the actual pagination mechanism - it's just kind of stupid that we paginate at all when we're usually looking at only hundreds of records per collection, we could provide a much better user experience on the frontend if we just paginated there. crisptrutski (Issue Creator) on (2024-04-09 07:39:03 UTC): In practice do we have a limit on how many records can be added to a collection? calherries on (2024-04-09 07:55:21 UTC): I don't think so. And Cam added pagination to improve the performance of loading large collections. Our own "Our Analytics" collection has >500 items in it, so it's not hard to believe there are collections out there with thousands of items. tsmacdonald on (2024-04-09 09:37:14 UTC): Possibly related: https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/30115#

body:
Epic https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/37306

### Description

While working on the crowded data labels issue I noticed we missed data labels default settings computation in the static viz. Also, for stacked series data labels z-index was not set correctly which resulted in labels showing below series.

title: Use DelayedLoadingAndErrorWrapper component in Admin > Performance
body:
As [discussed on Slack](https://metaboat.slack.com/archives/C02H619CJ8K/p1709558533499399) and elsewhere ([[1]](https://uxdesign.cc/should-you-delay-showing-the-user-that-something-is-loading-dd43077d5fc1), [[2]](https://mitchgavan.com/delay-loading-spinners-appearance/)), if a page takes a short amount of time to load, like around one fifth of a second, showing a loading spinner during that brief period of time can make the page feel slower than it really is.

This PR adds a `DelayedLoadingAndErrorWrapper` component, which is a version of the `LoadingAndErrorWrapper` component that shows nothing for the first 300ms, and then shows either the loading state (or the error state, if an error occurred).

This PR also uses this new `DelayedLoadingAndErrorWrapper` component in the Admin > Performance page

title: [Metrics V2] Create and execute queries based on metrics
body:
Fixes #41011
Fixes #41012
Fixes #41015

Updates query schema to use source-card and check metadata to create a query based on a metric.

When a `:metadata/card` object is passed to `lib/query` such as through `queryFromTableOrCardMetadata` the resulting query will have breakouts copied from the source metric and a reference to the metric in the aggregation.

title: fix image cut off
body:
Closes https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/37275
Closes https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/41278

### Description

The root cause was `yTicksWidthLeft` being too large. This happened because the `areDecimalTicksExpected` heuristic in `getYAxisTicksWidth` would be `true` even when the `number_style` column setting was set to `percent`, causing us to use the raw decimal value for the measurement, which was different from the actual value used.

To fix this we round the values to the nearest hundredth if `number_style` is `percent`.

### Demo

![Screenshot 2024-04-05 at 11.06.49 AM.png](https://graphite-user-uploaded-assets-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/9ULpbAzGBtvQRyZEpGvu/963a4c45-5c66-423e-99d8-88c22f642f29.png)

### Checklist

- [x] Tests have been added/updated to cover changes in this PR

Note that I've anonymized the question data before adding it as a test case.

title: Release migration locks during shutdown
body:
Closes https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/37866

### Description

This change updates our shutdown hooks to avoid leaving orphaned migration locks in the database, which require manual action to resolve.

If any locks are still held, we will wait a bit to see if they are released on their own, and otherwise we force release them.

While it's not ideal to release the locks while the migrations are still running, they are at least within a transaction, and their underlying connection is also closed thereafter preventing further statements from being run.

title: Re-enable Redshift uploads and make uploads tests faster
body:
Closes https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/41358

Does what it says on the tin:
1. Re-enables redshift uploads.
2. Refactors `create-csv-upload!` and cut some corners in tests to make them faster. Shaves off 5-6 minutes for redshift CI test runs

One controversial decision is Redshift doesn't support coercing integer columns to floats, so I decided to skip the feature where we automatically convert the column to float if there's a non-while float uploaded in an append / replace. Instead we throw an error if a user tries to upload a non-whole float to an integer column. So uploading a value like 1.0 still works, but uploading 1.1 doesn't. Because there's no driver-specific logic in `upload.types` that could help us rule out promoting the type from there, I decided to just throw an error from `driver/alter-columns!` if we try to change the column type: https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/41088/files#diff-46e2afe72e4fdc7fda5089fd547af5b814cdf0a451a51f16a8da93dad23aab63R513-R516 It might feel more correct to change `upload.types` to depend on driver-specific behaviour via a multimethod but to do it just for this feature is not with it imo.

Another potentially controversial decision is I leave around the test tables that we create for uploads tests, instead of dropping them immediately afterwards like we usually do. We still delete them at the end of the test run. This is to avoid test flakes which happen when we drop tables. Thankfully this is not a problem anymore because of https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/40310, which means these tables should not be synced in other tests.
author: calherries
labels: [('backport', 'Automatically create PR on current release branch on merge'), ('.Team/Workflows', 'aka BEC')]

Status Complete ‚ÜóÔ∏é

', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 4, 5, 15, 1, 34, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2048080834, 'issue_id': 2228215603, 'author': 'crisptrutski', 'body': '> Redshift doesn't support coercing integer columns to floats 1. We could consider supporting this in future through a "add column, update with cast, drop column, rename column" pattern, but the performance might be prohibitive. It's probably worth 2. Having drivers opt in or out for what conversions they support seems like a sensible future improvement, and by defaulting to "supports just int to float" this would not need to be breaking. 3. As mentioned in comment, I think we'll need better error messages. To save customers time and us support tickets. 4. Taking all the above into account, I think it's linking the comment back to a backlog item laying this out. > I leave around the test tables that we create for uploads tests It would be nice to have some eventual clean-up. Some combination of doing it all at once (e.g. teardown fixture for namespace) and only on some runs (e.g. on master) could mitigate flakes.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 4, 10, 17, 12, 57, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2049228553, 'issue_id': 2228215603, 'author': 'calherries', 'body': "> 3. As mentioned in comment, I think we'll need better error messages. To save customers time and us support tickets. Agreed, I was a bit lazy with the error message. The previous error message would be so annoying :D It's much better now in that it at least points out the column with the problem, I think the customer can throw the CSV in excel and fix the issue pretty easily themselves. > 4. Taking all the above into account, I think it's linking the comment back to a backlog item laying this out. I've added a TODO comment instead of a backlog issue, this is pretty subjective but I think it would be better to delay this until we run into more drivers with this issue or we want to support more type promotions. https://github.com/metabase/metabase/blob/1f66af770e3330ecb157fc3c367fc642035851fc/src/metabase/upload/types.cljc#L83-L84 > It would be nice to have some eventual clean-up. We are cleaning up the tables, but at the end of the test run. We do this for snowflake, redshift, bigquery, oracle", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 4, 11, 8, 52, 17, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2049323616, 'issue_id': 2228215603, 'author': 'github-actions[bot]', 'body': '@calherries Did you forget to add a milestone to the issue for this PR? _[When and where should I add a milestone?](https://www.notion.so/metabase/Metabase-Branching-Strategy-6eb577d5f61142aa960a626d6bbdfeb3?pvs=4#3dea255ffa3b4f74942a227844e889fa)_', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 4, 11, 9, 47, 26, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}]

title: Fix flaky `visualizations-tabular/object_detail.cy.spec.js`
body:
Closes https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/41084

### Description
This fixes the problem by ensuring that before we click the button it should be visible, I suspect this was caused by the slow runner and when we click the button before it was disabled, it will still used [the old `onclick` handler which was bound to other object.](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/blob/b7d1bb2139f2b309a43e9e9e9ddaba258bfde625/frontend/src/metabase/visualizations/components/TableInteractive/TableInteractive.jsx#L959)

### How to verify

Makes sure the stress test passes

- [x] Tests have been added/updated to cover changes in this PR
- [x] [Stress tests `master` failed] ‚ùå (https://github.com/metabase/metabase/actions/runs/8571030763/job/23490362410)
- [ ] [Stress tests this PR](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/actions/runs/8571497224) [x/20]

This PR is a part of the cleanup/follow up process after #40254.

It renames the `NativeQueryPreviewSidebar` to `NotebookNativePreview`, and it moves it to the Notebook directory.
This name suits better because:

2. The preview is not always shown as a sidebar

title: Faster driver/describe-database for redshift
body:
Redshift is flaking on `sql-jdbc.sync/current-user-table-privileges` for unknown reasons so this is an attempt to both remove that query and make sync faster in the process. Unfortunately the new query is still causing tests to flake, but it seems to have decreased their frequency.

Redshift sync still has a relatively slow and over-complicated `driver/describe-database` implementation.

The main reason it's slow is it performs a couple of queries per schema in series: one calls `has_schema_privilege` on each schema and the second gets the tables from each schema.

This PR speeds up `driver/describe-database` by doing one query for the whole database.

Quick benchmark on the "massive" test db:
```
(time (driver/describe-database :redshift db))
;; Before
; "Elapsed time: 225753.025583 msecs"
;; After
; "Elapsed time: 997.425083 msecs"
```
author: calherries

title: Do not i18n the logs
body:
I wrote some new Kondo linters that make sure you don't use i18n inside logs and went in and fixed everything.

Fixes #10764 
Fixes #15886

I also wrote a bunch of other linters that caught a ton of bugs which I fixed

- Warn if you're using something like `info` with a format string
- Warn if you're using i18n-style format placeholders like `{0}` in `infof` and the like
- Warn if `infof` and the like have the wrong number of args for its format string
- Warn if `u/format-color` has the wrong number of args for its format string
- Warn if using `info` and the like + `format` instead of `infof` 
- Warn against `e` in the wrong spot, e.g. `(log/info "whatever" e)` instead of `(log/info e "whatever")`
author: camsaul
labels: [('no-backport', 'Do not backport this PR to any branch'), ('.Team/Workflows', 'aka BEC')]

title: Simple sync exceptions
body:
Sync has over-engineered exception handling when we run tests that just makes the error messages worse and harder to find what the root cause is.

It chops off the most useful part of the stack trace and adds more layers of ExceptionInfo than we need to diagnose issues. Hand-crafted error messages are nice but long stack traces are better.

This PR removes most of the unnecessary layers of `ex-info`, while leaving the most important one that contains the connection info. This doesn't affect production, since these changes only affect the branches of the code where `*log-exceptions-and-continue?*` is false, which is only the case in tests.

Before: 
```
                clojure.lang.ExceptionInfo: Failed to create :redshift 'bird-flocks' test database: Failed to sync test database "bird-flocks": Error in sync step Sync redshift Database 483 ''bird-flocks'': Error in sync step Sync metadata for redshift Database 483 ''bird-flocks'': ERROR: relation "2024_03_21_3326bb73_b456_4070_8107_2c148dfc311c_schema.pvwhotmytavqnqdumsvp" does not exist

title: Preserve notebook native preview user preferences
body:
## What does this PR accomplish?
This PR adds two new entries to the user-local backend settings. Their sole purpose is to store the user preferences when it comes to the notebook native (query) preview.
- `notebook-native-preview-shown` (remembers the state of the preview)
    - I used "shown" instead of "open" because we're already using this terminology in the related Snowplow analytics
- `notebook-native-preview-sidebar-width` (remembers the last user-set sidebar width)

Speaking about the semantics, this PR also renames the previous entries used for the Redux store (uiControls) from:
- `isNativePreviewSidebarOpen` -> `isShowingNotebookNativePreview`
- `nativePreviewSidebarWidth` -> `notebookNativePreviewSidebarWidth`


```[tasklist]
### Tasks
- [x] Add backend setting
- [x] Add frontend types
- [x] Add Redux `action`(s)
- [x] Update `NativeQueryPreviewSidebar.tsx`
- [x] Update `NotebookContainer.tsx`
- [x] Add tests
```

> [!Important]
> The internal decision has been made to keep using both Redux and BE settings in parallel until we migrate settings endpoints to RTK. We're treating Redux as a fallback in meantime.

Technically, we're reading the BE settings and updating the Redux store while initializing the query builder. This gives us the option to read the values from the Redux store anywhere in the app, while only having to (dispatch) update BE settings from the application.

### How to test?
Toggling the native preview sidebar and resizing it should now be preserved as a user-local backend setting. This means that you should be able to log out and log in again, and your previous preferences should be preserved.

Alternatively, run the supplied E2E test.

epic #39977.

Fixes #39979.

Join @bshepherdson and the rest of your teammates on Graphite ', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 4, 4, 21, 45, 43, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2062244812, 'issue_id': 2226575350, 'author': 'bshepherdson', 'body': "The implementation here is working fine, but there's issues with the whole preview approach. It's possible when selecting several columns to combine (with eg. `concat` or `/`) to introduce a new column via an implicit join which is not available in the results. Some expressions don't need previews (eg. arithmetic) and are illustrated well by static examples (eg. date extractions). Other expressions (like `concat` with separators) benefit from a live example, but it's simpler and more robust to use placeholders or column names in that example instead of real values. So this PR is shelved, with no expectation that it will be resumed.", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 4, 17, 20, 42, 45, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}]
comment_thread:
bshepherdson (Issue Creator) on (2024-04-04 21:45:43 UTC): * **#41061** üëà * **#41251** * **#41060** * `master` This stack of pull requests is managed by Graphite. Learn more about stacking.

Join @bshepherdson and the rest of your teammates on Graphite bshepherdson (Issue Creator) on (2024-04-17 20:42:45 UTC): The implementation here is working fine, but there's issues with the whole preview approach. It's possible when selecting several columns to combine (with eg. `concat` or `/`) to introduce a new column via an implicit join which is not available in the results. Some expressions don't need previews (eg. arithmetic) and are illustrated well by static examples (eg. date extractions). Other expressions (like `concat` with separators) benefit from a live example, but it's simpler and more robust to use placeholders or column names in that example instead of real values. So this PR is shelved, with no expectation that it will be resumed.

title: [MBQL lib] Add "Combine columns" drill-thru, `lib/as-returned`, API changelog
body:
The drill-thru is mostly a stub to put an entry in the context menu. Most of the logic for this is built on the FE using the existing functions for consuming and creating expressions.

Another PR #41061 adds `Lib.previewExpression` to try out the under-construction expression on the first few rows of data from the query.

See [thread](https://metaboat.slack.com/archives/C06P22KS4JH/p1712264174056569) for a lot more context.

This also adds `docs/developer-guide/mbql-library-changelog.md` and documents adding this function to the library as the first change in the API. I'll follow up in another PR with Github automation to expect the changelog to be updated whenever `src/metabase/lib/js.cljs` changes.

Fixes #39978.

title: Nested queries have limits which can defeat their purpose
body:
Fixes https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/24969

Consider a query

```sql
select count(*) from {{#199}}
```

This query should return the number of distinct rows in the query defined by 199. But it's actually limited by the excel limit of 1048575 (meta note, ignore that this is a link. Github is being weird). And that's because when the value of `{{#199}}` is expanded it has that limit applied as normal.

```clojure
qp=> (let [card-id 199] ;; use a valid card id for you
       (-> {:database 1,
            :type :native,
            :native {:query "select count(*) from {{ref}}"
                     :template-tags {:ref {:card-id card-id
                                           :type :card
                                           :name "ref"
                                           :display-name "ref"}}}
            :middleware {:disable-max-results? true}} ;; note this middleware is not propagated to the subquery
           qp.compile/compile
           :query
           (metabase.db.query/format-sql )
           println))
select
  count(*)
from
  (
    SELECT
      "PUBLIC"."ORDERS"."ID" AS "ID",
      "PUBLIC"."ORDERS"."TOTAL" AS "TOTAL"
    FROM
      "PUBLIC"."ORDERS"
    LIMIT
      1048575         -- this is improper here
  )
```

I thought about trying to propagate that limit middleware, but i think it should not be the solution.
- that limit is actually not honored for the containing sql query
- we don't want to indiscriminately start adding that
- we might still want a limit on the _total_ query, but the inner query should be unbounded

When the parameter substitution code gets to the `{{#199}}` parameter tag, it compiles the query for card 199, which naturally includes the default excel limit. But we can suppress this limit specifically as a card parameter value when substituting a query inside yielding

```sql
select
  count(*)
from
  (
    SELECT
      "PUBLIC"."ORDERS"."ID" AS "ID",
      "PUBLIC"."ORDERS"."TOTAL" AS "TOTAL"
    FROM
      "PUBLIC"."ORDERS"
  )
```
author: dpsutton
labels: [('backport', 'Automatically create PR on current release branch on merge')]

title: fix modal padding
body:
Attempt to fix https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/41042

# Context

We sometimes use `<Modal>` directly, and sometimes we use the "long version"  of using the subcomponents (Modal.Root, Modal.Content etc)

The <Modal> component renders a structure like (simplified):
```
<{Equivalent of Modal.Root}>
  <Modal.Content>
    <Modal.Header/>
    <Modal.Body>
      {children}
    </Modal.Body>
  </Modal.Content>
</{Equivalent of Modal.Root}>
```
We had some default props on Modal.Body and Modal.Header, which were overriding the `padding` prop passed to `<Modal>`.
At the same time in some places we were passing a custom padding to `Modal.Content`, this was being *added* to the default ones for `Modal.Header` and `Modal.Body`. -> it's possible in some modals we're using the wrong padding by mistake (eg: the SaveQuestionModal has currently a padding of 40, which is not even in our theme)

# Solution

The solution I came with was to set the default padding to both Modal and to Modal.Root, they will both correctly forward it to both `Modal.Header` and `Modal.Body`.
In this way we are able to just pass the padding we want to either Modal or Modal.Root and it should work.

‚ö†Ô∏è Note that we should pass it to `Modal.Root`, and not to `Modal.Content`, otherwise the padding will be added to the default padding

In this PR I'm just "fixing"  `CreateApiKeyModal` and `SaveQuestionModal`, if the solution gets approved I/we'll have to fix all instances and make sure we're using the correct padding.


# How to verify
We need to verify that:
- the default padding of 32 is set for both `Modal` and `Modal.Root`
- both `Modal` and `Modal.Root` allow setting a custom padding via `padding` (`p` has weird behaviours, I'd avoid it)

For `Modal` we can test `CreateApiKeyModal` and for `Modal.Root` we can use `SaveQuestionModal`

title: [MBQL lib] `suggestedJoinConditions` accepts a join position for edits
body:
This optional fourth argument will disregard all joins at `position` and
later when suggesting conditions. This is useful when editing a join's
RHS, which wipes out the condition. We don't want to generate a
suggested condition that's based on keys from the RHS of the join we
just edited, or from later joins.

Fixes #40916. Part of #40890.
author: bshepherdson
labels: [('no-backport', 'Do not backport this PR to any branch')]

title: Updated Permissions UI - `view-data` UI E2E tests
body:
### Description

Adds e2e tests for the UI around our `view-data` permissions. I've pulled some of the tests out into a new `view-data` folder to help make some of the existing test suites a lot shorter and hopefully make things more organized. Goal is to do a follow-up PR that does the same thing for `create-queries`. I would like to get the tests around changing impersonation permissions moved into this folder, but I want to sync with @johnswanson about it first.

### Checklist

- [x] Tests have been added/updated to cover changes in this PR

title: cache invalidation via removal of query_cache entries
body:
New endpoint accepts entity and entity ids in form of `database=1&dashboard=2&question=3`. If you don't supply `&include=overrides`, then it tries to find configs directly referencing supplied entities and updates their `invalidated_at`. If you supply `&include=overrides`, removes `query_cache` entries for all referenced cards.

EE-only.

A variant of #40774 

resolves #40548
author: piranha
labels: [('no-backport', 'Do not backport this PR to any branch'), ('.Team/Workflows', 'aka BEC')]

title: make qp.middleware.cache-test/min-ttl-test pass consistently
body:
Undoing #40963 plus in theory test should be more reliable now. 

Default settings for `run-query` (with delay of 10 ms) make it run for 13-14 ms locally, but I imagine it could be significantly worse than that on a busy CI server. So getting this time up to 1000 ms should make this much more reliable.

On the contrary, there is no need to slow down query to 120 ms if a lower margin is 0.1 ms, default settings should be plently slow to trigger caching.

title: Capture card's last_used_at
body:
Milestone 3 of: https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/38229

We'd like to track when a card is last used, this is to power features like [Auto cleanup collections](https://www.notion.so/metabase/Auto-cleanup-collections-54b3b58e254a48e69b26a054c84fd944)

The challenge here is a card could be used as multiple things:
- a query
- a source for other queries
- definition for sandbox rules
- card reference in native query
- dashcard on dashboard
- alert/pulses

The naive way to update last_used_at would be go through each of these sources and update `last_used_at` manually. The problem with this approach is it's "manual", and thus error-prone if we add more features in the future.

~~So I tried to find the lowest common denominator of these features is that it all goes through the QP. 
And since QP has a nice thing called "cached metadata provider," where it's used as a cached layer for AppDB to fetch things like card/tables/fields that it needs to run a query.~~

~~So my idea is that at the end of the QP pipeline, we check this cached metadata provider to see which cards are in there and if a card is fetched during query execution, it must be useful :), and thus we should update its last_used_at.~~

~~Tech doc: https://www.notion.so/metabase/Capturing-last_used_at-last_viewed_at-45f16ce82494477688733b05596743fb?pvs=4#6dc37dcc8d1941698b8973af09a70afb~~

We've changed our mind and instead creates an `InvocationTracker` Metadata Provider, It acts as a wrapper for the existing `UncachedApplicationDatabaseMetadataProvider` where it keeps track of all card-ids that is called via `lib.metadata.protocols/card`. We can extend it further to track other methods call as well but `card` is all we need right now.
author: qnkhuat

title: fix relative date time x-axis ticks
body: Closes https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/40935 ### Description Fixes relative date time x-axes may have duplicated ticks. When a relative date time unit `day-of-week` is selected, the x-axis values are numbers formatted as days of week. ECharts may pick intermediate values for ticks like `1.5` that will appear as duplicates with formatting applied. This PR sets minInterval to numeric x-axes which is 1 for relative date time columns. ### How to verify - Create a chart summarized by a datetime dimension with day-of-week bucket - Filter out all days except Monday and Tuesday - Ensure there are no duplicated ticks ### Demo Before After ### Checklist - [x] Tests have been added/updated to cover changes in this PR

title: 40895 entity path in palette
body:
Closes https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/40895 

### Description
This PR adds collection and database names to search results and recent items in the command palette, as well as verified badges to items. This PR also adds keyboard navigation to the palette for `home`, `end`, `page up` and `page down` keys

### How to verify
1. Open the command palette and take a look at the recent items section, you should see the parent collections listed beside entities and database names listed beside tables.
2. Search for entities and tables, and you should see the same thing
3. Search for a verified question and you should see a verified badge next to the card name. 

### Demo
![chrome_nqyyj23XxM](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/assets/1328979/a1340864-a299-4bd0-b2b7-8e03866957de)

title: Make notebook native preview sidebar resizable
body:
This task belongs to the milestone 3 of #40254.

### Description
This PR introduces a resizable native query preview sidebar using a `ResizableBox` component from `react-resize` library.

Te biggest challenge while working on this task was to conditionally show either the resizable sidebar or the regular, full-width native query preview - all based on the current window width. The only solution I came up with was to literally display two distinct wrappers around the `NativeQueryPreviewSidebar` component. One is the resizable box and the other one is HTML 5 `aside`.

This required moving some of the logic from the CSS module directly to this component.

This PR also introduces a new key (`nativePreviewSidebarWidth`) to the redux store's `qb.uiControls` object.

### How to verify
1. Open a notebook view
2. Show SQL sidebar
3. It should initially be set to 428px
4. Try making it smaller - it should not be possible
5. Try resizing it to a bigger size
6. Close the sql preview
7. Open it again
8. Sidebar should've retained the last set width instead of the initial 428px
9. The maximum width of the sidebar is dictated by the min width of the notebook editor (which is 640px)

### Demo
https://github.com/metabase/metabase/assets/31325167/50053cba-3794-4f37-a598-b81248a2e494

--- 
> [!Important]
> I will cover this behavior with E2E tests in the upcoming PR that will persist both the sidebar state and the sidebar width to the backend user setting.

Please note that we've been able to re-enable the crucial E2E test for the CI thanks to changes in this PR. ReplayIO does not support nested media queries in the Chrome version yet. We got rid of the CSS module altogether so there's nothing stoping us from running this test in the CI again.
https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/40984/commits/e76e8de857b43654624598cd60ce4f6198a4687f

title: Use window functions for cumulative sum and cumulative count [BigQuery]
body:
Resolves #40992
Resolves #39837
Fixes #41053

As mentioned in #40752, all of our other SQL databases support one of the following ways of doing `ORDER BY` inside an `OVER` expression:
```sql
-- order by output column number
sum(sum(my_column) OVER (ORDER BY 1 ROWS UNBOUNDED PRECEDING) AS cumulative_sum
```

or 

```sql
-- copy order by from parent level of query
sum(sum(my_column) OVER (ORDER BY date_trunc(my_timestamp, 'month') ROWS UNBOUNDED PRECEDING) AS cumulative_sum
```

BigQuery however doesn't really fully support either. It doesn't support ordering by output column number at all. It doesn't support ordering by any sort of expression inside `OVER` other than a raw column identifier. So what do we do when we want to order by something like `date_trunc(column, 'month')` rather than just `column`?

Well, we have to introduce another stage that does the temporal bucketing (etc) so we can use plain identifiers in the windo function `ORDER BY`.

In Postgres. we compile this query

```clj
(-> (lib/query meta/metadata-provider (meta/table-metadata :orders))
    (lib/breakout (lib/with-temporal-bucket (meta/field-metadata :orders :created-at) :month))
    (lib/aggregate (lib/cum-sum (meta/field-metadata :orders :total))))
```
to

```sql
-- Postgres version
SELECT
  DATE_TRUNC('month', "public"."orders"."created_at") AS "created_at",
  SUM(SUM("public"."orders"."total")) OVER (
    ORDER BY
      DATE_TRUNC('month', "public"."orders"."created_at") ASC ROWS UNBOUNDED PRECEDING
  ) AS "sum"
FROM
  "public"."orders"
GROUP BY
  DATE_TRUNC('month', "public"."orders"."created_at")
ORDER BY
  DATE_TRUNC('month', "public"."orders"."created_at") ASC
```

In BigQuery we instead need to compile it to

```sql
-- BigQuery version
SELECT
  `source`.`created_at` AS `created_at`,
  SUM(SUM(`source`.`total`)) OVER (
    ORDER BY
      `source`.`created_at` ASC ROWS UNBOUNDED PRECEDING
  ) AS `sum`
FROM
  (
    SELECT
      `v4_test_data__transient_1712251964706.orders`.`total` AS `total`,
      TIMESTAMP_TRUNC(
        `v4_test_data__transient_1712251964706.orders`.`created_at`,
        month
      ) AS `created_at`
    FROM
      `v4_test_data__transient_1712251964706.orders`
  ) AS `source`
GROUP BY
  `created_at`
ORDER BY
  `created_at` ASC
LIMIT
  3
```

This PR introduces a new query transformation function to rewrite queries to look like that latter when needed -- actually fairly easy because of the MLv2 `lib.walk` stuff we added recently, especially the replace one stage with multiple stages stuff @snoe suggested.

I ended up removing the QP "upgrade field literals" middleware that replaced nominal field literal refs (string name instead of integer ID) with integer refs because it's not what we want to do going forward (we want to move toward using nominal field refs (string name) in all stages after the first) and it actually breaks more things than it fixes (it actually doesn't really fix anything except if you use a field literal ref with the wrong case, which shouldn't ever happen IRL). So that was a nice bonus.
author: camsaul
labels: [('no-backport', 'Do not backport this PR to any branch')]

title: React Testing Library V12
body:
Closes https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/40267

### Description
This PR updates React Testing Library up to v12.1.5, which is the furthest we can go before upgrading to React 18. The biggest change to RTL here is that the `waitFor` function will now use fake timers when `jest.useFakeTimers` is called. This has a fairly large impact when we're using fake timers while also doing things like waiting for loaders to be removed. In many cases, we can avoid using fake timers to have tests pass, but this can come with a performance impact. Some other small changes were needed, but this was by far the biggest breaking change

### How to verify
CI should pass

# Checklist

- [x] Tests have been added/updated to cover changes in this PR
author: npfitz
labels: [('backport', 'Automatically create PR on current release branch on merge')]

title: product-feedback endpoint
body:
**Note: I'm not a BE dev so any feedback is appreciated** üôè 

Part of  [[Epic] Initial homepage experience for embedding admins](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/40005)
[Eng plan](https://www.notion.so/metabase/Initial-homepage-experience-for-embedding-admins-was-Meet-embedders-at-the-door-full-version-63fa3a8e07634c9faf67d5bdd5a2df08?pvs=4#dbde642c901749cfa439b3989f299ea9)

This PR introduces a new endpoint, `/api/utils/product-feedback` which acts as a proxy towards harbor master to send feedback from within Metabase.

The endpoint will be used initially from the [FeedbackModal for the Embedding Homepage](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/40746).

By default, in dev mode it will use the value from an env as base domain, *even if empty*, this is by choice so that we don't send fake data to the real endpoint while testing the feature.
author: npretto
labels: [('.Team/Embedding', '')]
